name: Modern Africa: The Slave Trade to the End of Apartheid
base_name: Modern Africa: The Slave Trade to the End of Apartheid
long_desc: The course is designed to give students an understanding and appreciation of African history and culture from the inside out. Though it deals with the period of European expansion in Africa, it is centered on African language ethnic groups, villages, and individuals as historical actors who daily make collective and personal decisions to pass down, innovate, and borrow practices, technology, spiritual systems, etc. in the face of social, political, and economic realities. The course is also designed to get students thinking critically about how historians select and interpret sources to construct and reconstruct history at these different levels.This course fulfills Dietrich Colleges Intercultural and Global Inquiry general education requirement.

custom_fields.goals: The course is also designed to get students thinking critically about how historians select and interpret sources to construct and reconstruct history at these different levels.
custom_fields.key_topics:
1. the changes African cultures underwent since 1780, the period of growing European economic and political influence to the advent and aftermath of European colonization.
2. two common themes throughout the course are the re-distribution of resources and Africans' resistance.
3. The social processes in Africa and Africa's role in the global economy until the end of apartheid in 1994.
custom_fields.assessment_structure:
Three 4-page papers.

Class Participation - Class attendance and contributions to class discussion, small group meetings and presentations, small group evaluations, and attendance at 1 Africa-related event (we will attend as a class).

Journal Entry (about class Africa-related event).

Final Paper (8-page take home final exam).
custom_fields.relevance:
This course fulfills Dietrich College's "Intercultural and Global Inquiry" general education requirement.

The course is designed to give students an understanding and appreciation of African history and culture from the « inside out ». It is centered on African language/ethnic groups, villages, and individuals as historical actors who daily made collective and personal decisions to pass down, innovate, and borrow practices, technology, spiritual systems, etc. in the face of changing (and sometimes cataclysmic) social, political, and economic realities.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Texts, both primary and secondary sources.
custom_fields.extra_time_commitment: Attendance at one Africa-related event; we will attend as a class.
